My aunt and her daughter both died in their 40's from BC.  I feel blessed to have the time and not be rushed into a treatment decision. Posts.Content: Dec 14, 2010 06:50AM zogo wrote: Hi Kelly, I'm sitting in my bedroom recliner,  11 days post prophylactic bilateral mastectomy.  I was diagnosed with ALH, which really is not cancer and watch and wait, or tamoxifen were both options.  However, my family history would not escape my memory.  My paternal aunt died at 47 and her two daughters both got breast cancer.  One found a lump at 43, mammo showed nothing.  3 months later when she went back, it was too late.  She spent the rest of her life fighting cancer (immediate mx, chemo, rad) and died less than 2 years later.   I felt I did not want to wait around worrying every 6 months for the shoe to drop.  I want to live.  Even though I lost my nipples and have some skin necrosis after my diep flap, I can say I have no regrets. Hugs to you in your decision-making process, Jane

Posts.Content: Nov 3, 2010 12:14PM zogo wrote: When I had my stereostatic biopsy, there was a very nice assistant that stood right next to me the whole time.  The table is raised up high so she was right by my head.  The machine doesn't squeeze you nearly as tight at a mammogram.  Then they do some x-rays to find where they need to biopsy.  I actually found it very fascinating that they can pinpoint the area in question on a 3-D grid and the machine can go directly to that spot to take out the tissue.  I guess it is the engineer in me  =)  There was a little bit of pinching when they numbed the area and then just some pressure while they did the biopsy.  The assistant was right there to make sure I stayed calm and didn't jump.  The actual biopsy did not take long at all...just a few minutes.  I left with an ice pack and kept that on for much of that day.  I expected to have a giant bruise, but i never got anything more than a little pink mark at the point of entry.  Don't know if that was because mine was fairly deep . I hope it goes well for you and that the results are positive. Hugs

Posts.Content: Nov 4, 2010 07:11PM zogo wrote: Hi rc778, I can only give you my perspective on the subject....I was diagnosed in May with ALH and have a strong family history on my dad's side only.  My risk is around 40% .  It did take me a while to get my head around all the options and come to the conclusion that I would do a prophylactic bilateral mastectomy.  I am scheduled for Dec 3rd in Milwaukee.  Even though I often talk myself out of and back into it, I know it is the only option that will give me true peace of mind.  This is a wonderful forum, full of brave women at all stages.  I hope you will find plenty of information to help you through this difficult decision.
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed rc778 rc778

Posts.Content: Nov 24, 2010 01:18AM zogo wrote: Hi Kezzie,   My situation is a little different, but I will briefly share my story.  I have ALH and a strong family history on my father's side as well.  My aunt died at 47 and her daughter died at 45 (both from BC).  My risk is a little lower than yours, although my insurance wouldn't pay for risk analysis, I think it is around 40%.  I feel fortunate that I had time to wrap my head around all the options and make a decision without feeling rushed by the pressure of more advanced cancer.  I was afraid of Tamoxifen SE's as well.  My mom had a stroke in her early 50s and my dad had dementia.  The only other option was watch and wait.  I felt like that would stress me out 6 weeks out of every 6 months for the rest of my life.  And I would just be waiting for the other shoe to drop and then, like my cousin, spend the rest of my life fighting it.   I have chosen to be proactive and do a pbmx with immediate diep flap reconstruction.  My surgery is in 9 days.  I have talked myself out of and back into it MANY times.  However, at the end of the day, I know it is the only option that will give me true peace of mind. I hope you can come to a decision that is comfortable for you. Hugs

Posts.Content: Nov 18, 2010 06:59PM zogo wrote: Hi Jacqu79, Of course you are welcome here!  I'm having prophylactic BMx with Diep flap as well. Initially I wasn't sure if I fit in on this site either, but I have found nothing but wonderful and understanding women.  We are all afraid of the same kinds of things, regardless of our risk or stage.  Now I feel very at home and I hope you will, too.  Welcome and hugs! Mar, so sorry you are having a stressed day.  I got a lecture today from a relative, telling me that I think I am always strong and independent....but, I should ASK for help in this situation.  When people offer, I think they truly mean they will help with anything.  Whether it is a meal, a load of laundry, taking the garbage out, running to the store, please get a list of friends together and don't be afraid to call.  The most important thing you can do for yourself is to take the help and let yourself heal. It is going to take some time.  Hugs to all the Dec 2010 ladies!

Posts.Content: Dec 20, 2010 04:49AM zogo wrote: momof2greatkids.....thinking of you today as you head into surgery.  I hope all goes well for you and we will be waiting for you when you feel up to it.  Hugs Tina, I also have unhappy tissue.  It is skin (fortunately not flap) in two areas that looks black and crusty.  My PS will "fix" it on Wednesday.  Unfortunately I have to go under full anesthesia again.  Wish I didn't have to...I think it is b/c he is grafting some skin. vis0121, I admire you keeping your kids at the top of your priorities.  When we have children, life no longer allows us to  make decisions for ourselves alone.  When my 13 yo son (my youngest) told me he didn't want me to "go".  (die)  I promised him I would do everything I could to prevent that from happening.  And thus my decision for a mx.  When you get past all of this treatment, you will have a long and healthy life to spend with your family.  Hang tough girlfriend...it's worth the rocky ride.  Hugs BikerBabe, One day to go, and I know it must seem surreal.  I hope you have plenty to keep you busy today and lots of support on the other side.  You will do great and we will be here for you on the "other side" when you are up to it.   Megan, here's hoping you get those drains out as a xmas present!  Mine are being stubborn, too. Julia, I'm not very patient at being a patient either.  Sooo tired of sitting in this recliner. But after this long journey, I don't want to risk any complications with the flaps or diep incision. Elizabeth27, my insurance covered a couple home health care visits.  The nurse assessed the situation, watched my husband do the drains and discharged me.  I didn't think it was worth it.   Tammy, it sounds like you are doing fantastic in your recovery!  If you get info on the arm exercises, let us know....My numb forearm is driving me a bit crazy and I haven't got PT prescribed yet.  Gigi, it is so funny that you stumped your doctor with the Scuba question.  I hope you get a good answer, but it is better safe than sorry and wise of you to ask.  Andreas, congrats on getting through and getting home.  Happy healing and hugs!  Cathy, what did you pay you doctor to get him to tell your husband no chores for 2 years??  LOL  Sound like you are doing great and I hope your drains slow down for removal soon. Carolyn, how are those blisters?  Does it still seem like it is from the tape?  Hope they can help when you call the doc today. Carla, running in a couple weeks?  You go girl!  I'll be lucky if I can do a fast walk!  ArleneMarie, you make sure you don't overdo it on the upcoming move!  I can't imagine you recovering and moving at the same time...best of luck and let others do the work. Ilene, so glad to see you have joined the "recliner brigade".  We look forward to hearing your progress when it is easier to get online.  I know how tough it was for me at first.    Hugs to all my dear ladies on this thread....be well. Jane

Posts.Content: Nov 17, 2010 05:54PM zogo wrote: Ilene, I just read your bio on the NSM thread.  What a poignant story!  You have stated so many feelings that I can relate to. I can't do NSM due to my 38D size....but I trust my doctor to make them look good.  Here's a little of my background... My journey began in May, with calcifications and stereostatic biopsy.  Diagnosis was ALH and plan of action just watch and wait (or that and Tamoxifen).  I picture myself every 6 months stressing for 4 weeks before and a week after.  I think in the long run, that will be more stress over a lifetime than going through the pbmx and being able to get on with life. Unfortunately, I do have family history.  My aunt died at 47 and her two daughters both have BC.  One is on chemo now, the other discovered a lump, nothing showed up on mammo, a couple months later the lump got painful, they found invasive cancer, immediate mx , rads, chemo, and she spent the next 20 months, the remainder of her life, fighting it.  She died at age 45.  I never gave my family history much concern as it was on my Dad's side of the family.  After my ALH diagnosis, I couldn't stop thinking that I did not want to "watch and wait" for the shoe to drop.   Personally, I know this is the only option that will give me the most peace of mind. I have three teenagers, which can be a blessing and a curse (depending on the day) no really, I live for them.  A great DH that is supporting my every decision, and my mom (83) that lives nearby.  I'm just getting more nervous with only 2 weeks to go. What a great place this is to share and grab some calm.... Hugs to all my new friends, Jane

Posts.Content: Dec 2, 2010 12:49PM zogo wrote: Hi Gals, I'm really thrilled that we have so many ladies for our December club.  I guess that sounds bad considering what the reason is, but I am honored that you have joined.  Andrea- Brilliant idea with the double recliner!  Annie, so sorry you got delayed.  This waiting is agony.  Just took my before picture...ughh.  I also breast-fed babies (3) for quite a long time.  I made my surgeon reassure me I will get a lift.  Mar, good idea on the Hibiclens.  My husbands cousin got an infection after her tummy tuck and almost died.  The even put her in an induced coma.  So, we can't be too careful with germs.  (careful with your clothes and the hibiclens...I read it can stain.)  Does anybody have recommendations for soap afterwards?  I was told to use one separate bar for just the incision areas.  Maybe i will look for just plain dial antibacterial w/o moisturizers.  If you have glue, lotion can possibly dissolve it? Back to packing, Hugs ladies
Posts.Title: December 2010 Mastectomy zogo fire-dancer

Posts.Content: Dec 12, 2010 07:33AM zogo wrote: Andrea, sohardbnme , ArleneMarie, vis0121, I'm thinking of each of you as you head in for your mx's tomorrow.  Sending prayers for you and your doctors that all will go smoothly.   dfwgal, cancer free by Christmas is a wonderful thought.  By the end of the year for the remainder of our December Members!  I'm still hanging out in my bedroom recliner.  Trying to eat something before every dose of meds has me feeling like I'm eating all the time and not interested in food....that's a new one!  But, getting some of my favorites in, minus the coffee and chocolate I'm banned from.  Getting up has become easier and my bruise is getting smaller.  I get to see my BS tomorrow and hopefully I will get some drains out and we can come up with a plan for the skin that doesn't look so good.   Hugs
Posts.Title: December 2010 Mastectomy zogo fire-dancer

Posts.Content: Dec 13, 2010 03:59PM - edited Aug 20, 2013 04:23AM by zogo Greetings from the Bedroom Recliner, I got 4 of my 6 drains removed today. Yay!  I really wasn't expecting that many, as my PS needs to fix some skin necrosis and I figured he would leave those in until surgery next week.  It was great to get out of the house, but shortly after I got home, I was ready for a nap.  Elizabeth27, my situation is different, but I would wear the most comfortable thing you have.  The sleep cap sounds perfect.  From what I remember, I'm sure I didn't really care what I looked like after surgery and neither did any of the staff nor my family. You are beautiful the way you are.  Ilene, now it is truly time to "takeadeepbreath".  Try to smile and know I will be praying for you and your doctors tomorrow. Laurie, I'm guessing you have made it to NOLA by now.  Is cajun food too spicy for the night before surgery?  I love cajun cooking. Sending good karma your way for tomorrow. Carolyn, you are very brave to drive yourself in tomorrow.  I hope you will get sleep tonight.  And I will be thinking of you tomorrow... especially if I am awake at 5 am.  Hugs ladies, Jane

Posts.Content: Nov 16, 2010 04:47PM zogo wrote: Hi December Ladies, I posted a list of our surgeries by date at the top of the thread.  If I got something wrong or your date gets changed, just let me know.  antenut, It certainly sounds like your life will be full of testing in the near future.  I hope you get good results on them.  I know what you mean about surgery.  I just went for my pre-op and I had to sign all these papers with a list of all the things that could go wrong "including death".  Boy, if that doesn't make it real.....!!! Mar (Pink13) Know that I (and the gals on this site) will be here for you to talk and give support.  It must be hard missing your husband and having your kids be kind of distant.  Sending you a great big hug! Megan-fire I asked the nurse about the recliner today.  She said it is a good idea if you have one.  We are going to borrow one from my mom.  Now all I have to do is find room in my bedroom.  Ahh juggling funiture...I hate that....it always seems to touch more than one room. Sharon Two Mx's in one year?  Wow, I bet you will be glad when 2011 shows up!  You are a real trooper.  The idea to start a journal is brilliant!  I have one that I started and kind of forgot about.  I think it was a gratitude journal...with all the difficulties we are going through, gratitude is a good perspective to keep. Laurie,  I specifically asked my BS about my risk post surgery.  I'm sure it's not the same for all cases, but he gave me about 1%.  Compared to my 40% now.  That is one of the things that helped me decide to go ahead with the pbmx.   GiGi, you can always bring back shells from the beach for stocking stuffers!  Hugs all the way around!

Posts.Content: Nov 14, 2010 09:51PM zogo wrote: Hi Gigi, Glad you joined and are feeling well.  Dec 1st is coming up quickly.  Mine is Dec 3rd and I've started to get nervous about not getting things done beforehand.  I'm trying to get ready for Chrismas now, as I don't know how I'll feel afterwards. Laurie, thanks for the link....Dr Susan Love has so much good info on BC.  I will have to check it out. Hugs ladies
Posts.Title: December 2010 Mastectomy zogo fire-dancer

Posts.Content: Nov 22, 2010 06:07AM - edited Aug 20, 2013 05:14AM by zogo Andrea  lol, let's hope by February we will all be through this and on the mend.  Hopefully the weight of this will be lifted the next time you go to NZ.   My PS's nurse told me no lifting more than 5 lbs and no pushing / pulling, like vacuuming. But, so many women use the recliner, and I have never heard getting in/out mentioned either.  Maybe leg muscles help with the un-recline? Now I'm curious.... Hi citykitty and welcome to the December group! I can so relate to you needing to do research...I am the research queen.  I probably know too much at this point and am scared to be going through this as well.  After researching the internet to death, I find myself on this website all the time.  I made the decision in Sept. to get a prophylactic BMx and have been waiting since then to get a time with my surgeons.  At the end of the day, I do know that this decision will give me the greatest chance at "peace of mind", which in my book, is priceless. Gigi welcome home!  Hope you soaked up the sun and got some relaxation.  It seems even if I'm doing nothing now, it's hard to relax.  I guess busy is better, which is not bad, given the list of things I still have to do! Tina thanks for honoring us with your first post! I hope you feel warm and welcome... you are in very good company with all of these brave and beautiful ladies.  You are officially in charge of keeping us all laughing!  What a great attitude.

Posts.Content: Nov 29, 2010 05:11AM zogo wrote: Hello Carolyn (riley702), Thanks for coming over to join.  Was the robe belt from a robe you brought or from a hospital robe?  Sounds like a good tip. Anniemomofthree, Welcome! Well you must be insanely busy with three small kids and the holidays right around the corner. Sending hugs sammolisa, thanks for the tips, I guess we will need help, it is so hard to picture being that helpless.  I can't wait to get this over, but I do realize that is when the work (of healing) starts.  So, I had my first pre surgery dream last night. My abdomen incision came unglued and I couldn't get ahold of my doctor (or my dentist, lol, as if he could help). Does that fall in the nightmare category?   I am hoping to get one last trip to Costco in today for stocking up.  I know it will be a while before I can tackle that again.  Hugs to all of you, Jane

Posts.Content: Dec 10, 2010 06:38AM zogo wrote: Good Morning, Greetings from the Bedroom Recliner, Bridget, glad to see you are well enough to go out for breakfast and a big fat zero!  I'm a big fat zero too! Doing the Happy Dance very slowly with no flailing arms.  Path report came back all negative.  My right forearm has been numb since surgery.  I don't know if it was placement of my arms during the long procedure or the lymph node they took.  I had SO many IV's that had to be tried, (tried again then call the IV team who sometimes had to also try twice) placed, changed. At least 12 IV pokes I can count.  Maybe the total count is in the journal my friend/husband started.  Not to mention heparin injections in the thigh every 8 hours. Then my blood sugar was a little up just after surgery.  I'm not diabetic, but then they insisted on poking me 4 times a day for blood sugar and even gave me a couple insulin shots.  I have bruises all over me and am glad to not be getting poked anymore.  The morning of day 5 after surgery, I was hoping to get the ok to come home and the IV in my numb arm got so painful, they thought I might be having a heart attack.  Just Great! Out comes the EKG and blood work (another poke) for MI enzymes. I have a couple small areas that are purple where the BS probably scraped too close to the skin and will have to have some minor skin grafting done.  Another surgery, very soon, dread that.  But, swelling is down a bit and I'm online.  Anniemomofthree, Good luck with the SNB tomorrow. Annie62, you are so lucky to escape the pain meds.  I'm hating the oxycodone. BikerBabe, dfwgal, I've added you to the list no one wants to be on.  But we want you here with us, WELCOME! Did I miss anyone else?  Send a reminder if I did. Hugs, Mar, Ilene, Megan, and all my other December sisters,

Posts.Content: Dec 16, 2010 04:36PM zogo wrote: vis0121, In the Hospital, I was getting zofran and droperidal for nausea.  Neither helped much.  Then they tried Benedryl by IV and it worked in what seemed to be 5 minutes.  From then on, I was using Benedryl for nausea and bought some to counteract my pain meds at home.  Please give this a try to see if you can better tolerate the pain meds.  You heal better if you are not in pain.  Although I will say that I like the clear head w/o the meds. I hope that tip might help you, Hugs,

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2011 06:04AM zogo wrote: Paula, How are you today?  Any less swollen?  If not, make that call.  Hugs Tina, sounds like work is a great place.  We should all be so lucky to have a job like that!  Summer, what did you find out from the path report?  Praying for you. Anniemomofthree, sorry about your port being painful.  Better than hurting your veins though!  My dead skin graft is changing...I guess it is healing, but still most ugly to me. I can't imagine how this will heal into anything that looks ok.  Especially the part under the fold.  But the flap is alive and safe, so the skin is secondary to that. Sending out good karma to all my December ladies....hugs!
